segment.source: Async programming and DirectX
segment.target: Async programming and DirectX

segment.source: If you're just learning about DirectX, or even if you're experienced with it, consider putting all your graphics processing pipeline on one thread.
segment.target: If you're just learning about DirectX, or even if you're experienced with it, consider putting all your graphics processing pipeline on one thread.

segment.source: In any given scene in a game, there are common resources such as bitmaps, shaders, and other assets that require exclusive access.
segment.target: In any given scene in a game, there are common resources such as bitmaps, shaders, and other assets that require exclusive access.

segment.source: These same resources require that you synchronize any access to these resources across the parallel threads.
segment.target: These same resources require that you synchronize any access to these resources across the parallel threads.

segment.source: Rendering is a difficult process to parallelize across multiple threads.
segment.target: Rendering is a difficult process to parallelize across multiple threads.

segment.source: However, if your game is sufficiently complex, or if you are looking to get improved performance, you can use asynchronous programming to parallelize some of the components that are not specific to your rendering pipeline.
segment.target: However, if your game is sufficiently complex, or if you are looking to get improved performance, you can use asynchronous programming to parallelize some of the components that are not specific to your rendering pipeline.

segment.source: Modern hardware features multiple core and hyperthreaded CPUs, and your app should take advantage of this!
segment.target: Modern hardware features multiple core and hyperthreaded CPUs, and your app should take advantage of this!

segment.source: XAML-based UI components
segment.target: XAML-based UI components

segment.source: Your app can handle these components on multiple concurrent threads.
segment.target: Your app can handle these components on multiple concurrent threads.

segment.source: File I/O, especially asset loading, benefits greatly from asynchronous loading, because your game or app can be in an interactive state while several (or several hundred) megabytes of assets are being loaded or streamed.
segment.target: File I/O, especially asset loading, benefits greatly from asynchronous loading, because your game or app can be in an interactive state while several (or several hundred) megabytes of assets are being loaded or streamed.

segment.source: The easiest way to create and manage these threads is by using the Parallel Patterns Library and the task pattern, as contained in the concurrency namespace defined in PPLTasks.h.
segment.target: The easiest way to create and manage these threads is by using the Parallel Patterns Library and the task pattern, as contained in the concurrency namespace defined in PPLTasks.h.

segment.source: Using the Parallel Patterns Library takes direct advantage of multiple core and hyperthreaded CPUs, and can improve everything from perceived load times to the hitches and lags that come with intensive CPU calculations or network processing.
segment.target: Using the Parallel Patterns Library takes direct advantage of multiple core and hyperthreaded CPUs, and can improve everything from perceived load times to the hitches and lags that come with intensive CPU calculations or network processing.

segment.source: Note In a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, the user interface runs entirely in a single-threaded apartment (STA).
segment.target: Note In a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, the user interface runs entirely in a single-threaded apartment (STA).

segment.source: If you are creating a UI for your DirectX game using XAML interop, you can only access the controls by using the STA.

segment.source: Multithreading with Direct3D devices
segment.target: Multithreading with Direct3D devices

segment.source: Multithreading for device contexts is only available on graphics devices that support a Direct3D feature level of 11\_0 or higher.
segment.target: Multithreading for device contexts is only available on graphics devices that support a Direct3D feature level of 11\_0 or higher.

segment.source: However, you might want to maximize the use of the powerful GPU in many platforms, such as dedicated gaming platforms.
segment.target: However, you might want to maximize the use of the powerful GPU in many platforms, such as dedicated gaming platforms.

segment.source: In the simplest case, you might want to separate the rendering of a heads-up display (HUD) overlay from the 3D scene rendering and projection and have both components use separate parallel pipelines.
segment.target: In the simplest case, you might want to separate the rendering of a heads-up display (HUD) overlay from the 3D scene rendering and projection and have both components use separate parallel pipelines.

segment.source: Both threads must use the same ID3D11DeviceContext to create and manage the resource objects (the textures, meshes, shaders, and other assets), though, which is single-threaded, and which requires that you implement some sort of synchronization mechanism (such as critical sections) to access it safely.
segment.target: Both threads must use the same ID3D11DeviceContext to create and manage the resource objects (the textures, meshes, shaders, and other assets), though, which is single-threaded, and which requires that you implement some sort of synchronization mechanism (such as critical sections) to access it safely.

segment.source: And, while you can create separate command lists for the device context on different threads (for deferred rendering), you cannot play those command lists back simultaneously on the same ID3D11DeviceContext instance.
segment.target: And, while you can create separate command lists for the device context on different threads (for deferred rendering), you cannot play those command lists back simultaneously on the same ID3D11DeviceContext instance.

segment.source: Now, your app can also use ID3D11Device, which is safe for multithreading, to create resource objects.
segment.target: Now, your app can also use ID3D11Device, which is safe for multithreading, to create resource objects.

segment.source: So, why not always use ID3D11Device instead of ID3D11DeviceContext?
segment.target: So, why not always use ID3D11Device instead of ID3D11DeviceContext?

segment.source: Well, currently, driver support for multithreading might not be available for some graphics interfaces.
segment.target: Well, currently, driver support for multithreading might not be available for some graphics interfaces.

segment.source: You can query the device and find out if it does support multithreading, but if you are looking to reach the broadest audience, you might stick with single-threaded ID3D11DeviceContext for resource object management.
segment.target: You can query the device and find out if it does support multithreading, but if you are looking to reach the broadest audience, you might stick with single-threaded ID3D11DeviceContext for resource object management.

segment.source: That said, when the graphics device driver doesn't support multithreading or command lists, Direct3D 11 attempts to handle synchronized access to the device context internally; and if command lists are not supported, it provides a software implementation.
segment.target: That said, when the graphics device driver doesn't support multithreading or command lists, Direct3D 11 attempts to handle synchronized access to the device context internally; and if command lists are not supported, it provides a software implementation.

segment.source: As a result, you can write multithreaded code that will run on platforms with graphics interfaces that lack driver support for multithreaded device context access.
segment.target: As a result, you can write multithreaded code that will run on platforms with graphics interfaces that lack driver support for multithreaded device context access.

segment.source: If your app supports separate threads for processing command lists and for displaying frames, you probably want to keep the GPU active, processing the command lists while displaying frames in a timely fashion without perceptible stutter or lag.
segment.target: If your app supports separate threads for processing command lists and for displaying frames, you probably want to keep the GPU active, processing the command lists while displaying frames in a timely fashion without perceptible stutter or lag.

segment.source: In this case, you could use a separate ID3D11DeviceContext for each thread, and to share resources (like textures) by creating them with the D3D11\_RESOURCE\_MISC\_SHARED flag.
segment.target: In this case, you could use a separate ID3D11DeviceContext for each thread, and to share resources (like textures) by creating them with the D3D11\_RESOURCE\_MISC\_SHARED flag.

segment.source: In this scenario, ID3D11DeviceContext::Flush must be called on the processing thread to complete the execution of the command list prior to displaying the results of processing the resource object in the display thread.
segment.target: In this scenario, ID3D11DeviceContext::Flush must be called on the processing thread to complete the execution of the command list prior to displaying the results of processing the resource object in the display thread.

segment.source: Deferred rendering
segment.target: Deferred rendering

segment.source: Deferred rendering records graphics commands in a command list so that they can be played back at some other time, and is designed to support rendering on one thread while recording commands for rendering on additional threads.
segment.target: Deferred rendering records graphics commands in a command list so that they can be played back at some other time, and is designed to support rendering on one thread while recording commands for rendering on additional threads.

segment.source: After these commands are completed, they can be executed on the thread that generates the final display object (frame buffer, texture, or other graphics output).
segment.target: After these commands are completed, they can be executed on the thread that generates the final display object (frame buffer, texture, or other graphics output).

segment.source: Create a deferred context using ID3D11Device::CreateDeferredContext (instead of D3D11CreateDevice or D3D11CreateDeviceAndSwapChain, which create an immediate context).
segment.target: Create a deferred context using ID3D11Device::CreateDeferredContext (instead of D3D11CreateDevice or D3D11CreateDeviceAndSwapChain, which create an immediate context).
